title: The `simp` tactic

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.neg_one_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (v : V) : -1 • v = -v

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.smul_zero_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (a : K) : a • 0 = 0

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_contains_zero
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) : 0 ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.subspace_neg
lemmas.altTitle:
{K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) {W}
  (hW : LinearAlgebraGame.isSubspace W) (x : V) (a✝ : x ∈ W) : -x ∈ W

lemmas.name: LinearAlgebraGame.zero_smul_v
lemmas.altTitle: {K V} (fk : Field K) (acg : AddCommGroup V) (vs : LinearAlgebraGame.VectorSpace K V) (w : V) : 0 • w = 0

lemmas.name: MulAction.mul_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {β} [Monoid α] [MulAction α β] (x y : α) (b : β) : (x * y) • b = x • y • b

lemmas.name: Nat.add_succ
lemmas.altTitle: (n m : ℕ) : n + Nat.succ m = Nat.succ (n + m)

lemmas.name: add_right_cancel
lemmas.altTitle: {G} [Add G] [IsRightCancelAdd G] {a b c} (a✝ : a + b = c + b) : a = c

lemmas.name: add_smul
lemmas.altTitle: {R} {M} [Semiring R] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module R M] (r s : R) (x : M) : (r + s) • x = r • x + s • x

lemmas.name: le_iff_exists_add
lemmas.altTitle: {α} [CanonicallyOrderedAddCommMonoid α] {a b} : a ≤ b ↔ ∃ c, b = a + c

lemmas.name: one_smul
lemmas.altTitle: (M : Type u_1) {α} [Monoid M] [MulAction M α] (b : α) : 1 • b = b

lemmas.name: smul_add
lemmas.altTitle: {M} {A} [AddZeroClass A] [DistribSMul M A] (a : M) (b₁ b₂ : A) : a • (b₁ + b₂) = a • b₁ + a • b₂

lemmas.name: symm
lemmas.altTitle: {α} {r} [IsSymm α r] {a b} (a✝ : r a b) : r b a

introduction:
The `simp` tactic aims to simplify your goal. Often if a goal seems very complicated, or uses
definitions that need to be unfolded, the `simp` tactic will make progress.

`simp` is not a flawless tool, and there are many simple statements it cannot prove, although when
used correctly, it can be very useful.

In this level, your goal is to prove an equality about certain elements in a "Group". A group is a
mathematical object where elements in a group can be multiplied together in a way that "makes sense".
Examples of groups involve the real numbers, integers, invertible square matrices of a specific size,
and many more. `simp` knows many theorems about groups, and is able to simplify and solve most
simple statements about them.

In this level, `a b c` are all elements of G, `1` is the multiplicative identity of G, and `a⁻¹` is
the multiplicative inverse of `a`. You can see that both sides of the equation will cancel out to `b`,
but there is an easy way to prove that they are equal.
descrFormat: example (G : Type) (hg : Group G) (a b c : G)  : a * a⁻¹ * 1 * b = b * c * c⁻¹  := by
conclusion:
`simp` will be very useful when solving simple equations in future worlds. You can always
read more about it by clicking on it on the right.
